Jane's worked here for some time (= for a fairly long period of time).
Do it now please—not in three hours' time (= three hours from now).
The journey time is two hours.
I don’t want to take up too much of your precious time.
What’s the hurry? We have all the time in the world.

senses.definition: a period of time, either long or short, during which you do something or something happens

examples.x: His injuries will take a long time to heal.
It took them a long time to get home.
Did you have to wait a long time to see the doctor?
I lived in Egypt for a time.
I was only there for a short time.
The early morning is the best time of day.
Her parents died a long time ago.
At one time (= at a period of time in the past) Emily was my best friend.
Mr Curtis was the manager in my time (= when I was working there).

senses.definition: a period of history connected with particular events or experiences in people’s lives

examples.x: The movie is set at the time of the Russian Revolution.
the politician who promised ‘peace in our time’
in ancient times
The Industrial Revolution took place in Victorian times.
the violent times we live in (= the present period of history)
in times of trouble
The business was successful, even during difficult times.
Times are hard for the unemployed.
Times have changed since Grandma was young.

senses.definition: an occasion when you do something or when something happens the first/last time (that) I…

examples.x: Every time I hear that song I feel happy.
It doesn't matter if you don't win every time (= every time you play).
Next time you're here let's have lunch together.
He failed his driving test three times.
He's determined to pass this time.
When was the last time you saw her?
I see her two or three times a week.
How many times (= how often) do I have to tell you not to do that?
I remember one time (= once) we had to abandon our car in the snow.
At no time did I give my consent to the plan.

senses.definition: an event or occasion that you experience in a particular way

examples.x: Did you have a good time in Spain?
They're having a hard time dealing with her illness.
I had an awful time in the hospital.
Mike and I shared some really good times.

senses.definition: how long somebody takes to run a race or complete an event

examples.x: The winner's time was 11.6 seconds.
She completed the 500 metres in record time (= faster than any previous runner).
one of the fastest times ever

senses.definition: the number of beats (= units of rhythm) in a bar of music

examples.x: This piece is in four-four time.
a slow waltz time
The conductor beat time with a baton.

senses.definition: the correct speed and rhythm of a piece of music

examples.x: Try and dance in time to the music (= with the same speed and rhythm).
Clap your hands to keep time (= sing or move with the correct speed and rhythm).
to play in/out of time (= follow/not follow the correct speed and rhythm)
He always plays in perfect time.

senses.definition: the emperor of Russia in the past

examples.x: Tsar Nicholas II

senses.definition: an official whose job is to advise the government on policy in a particular area

examples.x: a drugs tsar
a drug tsar

senses.definition: the empress of Russia in the past
the emperor of Russia in the past
an official whose job is to advise the government on policy in a particular area
connected with the period from 1837 to 1901 when Queen Victoria was queen in the UK

examples.x: Victorian architecture
the Victorian age

senses.definition: having the attitudes that were typical of society during Queen Victoria’s reign Victorian values

examples.x: Victorian attitudes to sex (= being easily shocked by sexual matters)
She advocated a return to Victorian values (= hard work, pride in your country, etc.).

senses.definition: a British person who was alive during the period from 1837 to 1901, when Queen Victoria was queen
the period during which a country is fighting a war

examples.x: Different rules applied in wartime.

senses.definition: from or connected with a period during which a country is fighting a war

examples.x: Fruit was a luxury in wartime Britain.
her wartime experiences

senses.definition: the general mood or quality of a particular period of history, as shown by the ideas, beliefs, etc. common at the time
